title: GitHub is an effective platform for collaborative and reproducible laboratory research
authors: Katharine Y. Chen, Maria Toro-Moreno, Arvind Rasi Subramaniam
keyAssumptions: Version control systems are primarily for software development; Scientific research requires specialized collaboration tools; Git workflows are too technical for researchers
citation: Chen, K. Y., Toro-Moreno, M., & Subramaniam, A. R. (2024). GitHub is an effective platform for collaborative and reproducible laboratory research. arXiv preprint arXiv:2408.09344.
notes: Demonstrates adaptation of software development workflows to laboratory research lifecycle management. Provides three-step framework: experiment organization via issues/boards, documentation with version control, reproducible environments with containers.

title: An open framework for archival, reproducible, and transparent science
keyAssumptions: Making data and code available is sufficient for reproducibility; Computational environments can be described in text; Static archives are adequate for preservation
citation: Dasgupta, S., & Nuyujukian, P. (2024). An open framework for archival, reproducible, and transparent science. arXiv preprint arXiv:2504.08171.
notes: ARTS framework integrates containers, version control, and persistent archives. Addresses reproducibility crisis by preserving complete computational contexts, not just data and code.

title: AgentRxiv: Towards Collaborative Autonomous Research
keyAssumptions: AI research agents should work independently; Scientific collaboration requires human mediation; AI agents cannot build upon each other's work
citation: Schmidgall, S., et al. (2025). AgentRxiv: Towards Collaborative Autonomous Research. arXiv preprint arXiv:2503.18102.
notes: Framework enabling AI agent collaboration through shared preprint server. Demonstrates 11.4% performance improvement when agents access prior research vs isolation. Shows potential for AI-AI research collaboration.

title: Procedural Knowledge Libraries: Towards Executable (Research) Memory
keyAssumptions: Research outputs are primary valuable artifacts; Research processes are too complex to capture; Static documentation is sufficient
citation: Oderinwale, H., et al. (2025). Procedural Knowledge Libraries: Towards Executable (Research) Memory. arXiv preprint arXiv:2506.14715.
notes: PKL framework captures complete research processes including failures, decisions, iterations. Proposes executable memory for research beyond static outcomes. Extends version control to decision-making rationales.

title: Managing Software Provenance to Enhance Reproducibility in Computational Research
keyAssumptions: Individual researchers can adequately manage computational experiment documentation; HPC complexity makes systematic documentation impractical
citation: Dhruv, A., & Dubey, A. (2023). Managing Software Provenance to Enhance Reproducibility in Computational Research. arXiv preprint arXiv:2308.15637.
notes: Systematic provenance tracking for HPC computational experiments. Demonstrates feasibility of comprehensive documentation in complex computing environments. Addresses scientific computing reproducibility challenges.

title: How Scientists Use Jupyter Notebooks: Goals, Quality Attributes, and Opportunities
keyAssumptions: Scientists primarily use notebooks for linear exploration; Notebook design requirements are well-understood; Scientists' practices mirror professional developers
citation: Huang, R. L., et al. (2025). How Scientists Use Jupyter Notebooks: Goals, Quality Attributes, and Opportunities. arXiv preprint arXiv:2503.12309.
notes: Observational study of 20 scientists using Jupyter notebooks. Reveals goal-dependent quality priorities, state management challenges, and need for sophisticated dependency tracking. Informs version control requirements for scientific workflows.
